an10.48:0.3: 48. Ten Regular Reflections for a Renunciate
an10.48:1.1: “Mendicants, one who has gone forth should often review these ten things.
an10.48:2.1: One who has gone forth should often review this: ‘I have secured freedom from class.’
an10.48:3.1: ‘My livelihood is tied up with others.’
an10.48:5.1: ‘I hope there’s no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct?’
an10.48:6.1: ‘I hope that, after examination, sensible spiritual companions don’t reproach any aspect of my ethics?’
an10.48:7.1: ‘I must be parted and separated from all I hold dear and beloved.’
an10.48:8.1: ‘I am the owner of my deeds and heir to my deeds. Deeds are my womb, my relative, and my refuge.
an10.48:9.1: I shall be the heir of whatever deeds I do, whether good or bad.’
an10.48:10.1: ‘As the days and nights flit by, what sort of person am I becoming?’
an10.48:11.1: ‘Do I love to stay in empty huts?’
an10.48:12.1: ‘Do I have any superhuman distinctions in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, so that when my spiritual companions question me on my deathbed I will not be embarrassed?’
an10.48:13.1: One who has gone forth should often review these ten things.”
